qas.question: Which forest is the largest national forest in the US?
Which city was Alaska's former capital?
What is the area closest to the continental US called?
Where did most settlement occur after the Louisiana Purchase?
Which forest is the smallest national forest in the US?
Which forest is the largest national forest in the UN?
Which city was Alaska's current capital?
What is the area farthest to the continental US called?
Where did least settlement occur after the Louisiana Purchase?

context: Also referred to as the <a2_0><a3_0><b7_0><b8_0>Panhandle or Inside Passage<b8_0/><b7_0/><a3_0/><a2_0/>, this is the region of Alaska closest to the rest of the United States. As such, this was where most of the initial non-indigenous settlement occurred in the years following the Alaska Purchase. The region is dominated by the Alexander Archipelago as well as the <a0_0><b4_0><b5_0>Tongass National Forest<b5_0/><b4_0/><a0_0/>, the largest national forest in the United States. It contains the state capital Juneau, the former capital <a1_0><b6_0>Sitka<b6_0/><a1_0/>, and Ketchikan, at one time Alaska's largest city. The Alaska Marine Highway provides a vital surface transportation link throughout the area, as only three communities (Haines, Hyder and Skagway) enjoy direct connections to the contiguous North American road system.
